I assume the DB is always returning UTC, even if the timezone is set on the host?

postgres timezone setting is UTC, see postgresql.conf

timezone = UTC

future enhancement consideration: purge/hard-delete records only when there are more than a certain number of entries in the database; i.e. could exit early if there are not many soft deleted records.  We've seen thousands; so a threshold on count could be trigger to start the hard delete in addition to date.
The thousands of failed orch requests are due to an issue with identity sync (tracked by another LP). We don't want to mask it with the hard delete.

This assumes that it's impossible to have two entries with the same timestamp.  As long as that's true then this would be okay.  If we could ever get two entries with the same timestamp I think we'd want it to be "<".

Orch requests are updated by individual sync threads. The updated_at timestamps are of this format
2020-04-27 22:00:23.351513
2020-04-27 22:00:23.393549
2020-04-27 22:00:23.538667
2020-04-27 22:00:23.549766
2020-04-27 22:00:23.622286
2020-04-27 22:00:23.724265
2020-04-27 22:00:23.725094
2020-04-27 22:00:23.741374

It's highly unlikely that there are multiple orch requests with the same updated_at timestamp. The <= condition ensures that failed orch requests, prior to the current audit cycle, with the same updated_at timestamps will all get soft deleted.

distributedcloud/dcorch/db/sqlalchemy/mi.message: Just curious - why are we adding the indexes?

These are for the queries used in new db api. e.g. without the ORCH_JOB_ID index, purging orch_request table of ~8500 records  and 1400 of which are soft deleted would take 8-9 seconds as opposed to 200-300ms.

I'm a bit conflicted about all of these...not sure what's better, update the indices every time an orch_request gets updated/deleted/created (which is potentially a lot, especially during subcloud addition), or just do a non-indexed scan through all of the orch_requests when the audit runs.

Subcloud addition/deletion and system wide resource changes such as dns/certificate change, project/user/flavor create is not a frequent event.

I don't have good data to determine which is more optimal, with or without indices. Based on the data in the lab environment with a couple of outstanding identity related sync issues, the timing of the new query (get most recent failed request) which is frequently used at steady state as well as purge timing are better with indices.

In any case, the number of records are expected to be in the thousands at most, not millions. We can reevaluate these indices once identity sync related issues have been addressed.

I don't think this is valid, because we could be racing with the sync() thread that just got new work added.  I think it'd be better to just call wake(), and if there's really no work then the sync thread will send the "in sync" status.

I think we probably want to call self.wake() here since the sync() thread may have already finished processing the sync requests by the time we get here and we need to delete the failed requests first in order to know whether we're in sync.

I *think* we can probably get away with not calling wake() if there weren't any failed requests.

kernel-modules/intel-opae-fpga/centos/pa.message: Did Shuicheng write this patch and you made no change to it at all (other than context changes ie. @@ lines?
Why does your last name show as Che instead of Chen?  Just a reminder that patch files must always be regenerated and not directly edited, leading to issues like this.

Subject should not have -'s between words.

Yeah, the tools don't make this stuff easy, feel free to upvote https://bugs.launchpad.net/starlingx/+bug/1856897

I don't understand the actual issue here.  You remove a direct call to uname -r and instead replace it with KERNELDIR which contains uname -r in it?  Makes no sense to me.  Why not just fix the sed script if there's a problem with what it produces?

The current compilation environment is to build a mock environment in the container for compilation. The "uname -r" command obtains the host kernel version, not the kernel version in the mock. KERNELDIR will be passed in by spec (the kernel version actually involved in the compilation, obtained by the "rpm -q kernel-devel" command), but not by "uname -r". So kerval gets the correct value through KERNELDIR.

base/rt-setup/centos/meta_patches/0001-U.message: Since this is a new patch, we don't need to say TIS here, this is StarlingX
I prefer to keep it. Then from package name, we could know it is built by STX, not pure centos upstream package. And know where to find this package if we want to look into.

If this patch is not used, it cannot be compiled.

ERROR: /localdisk/loadbuild/zs/starlingx/rt/srpm_assemble/rt-setup/rpmbuild/SPECS/rt-setup.spec: 'Release' must use %{?_tis_dist}.%{tis_patch_ver} or %{tis_patch_ver}%{?_tis_dist}

The plan is to move away from using TiS in any patch names, using STX instead.  TiS (Titanium Server) is a Wind River specific name, and Saul and I don't want to see new packages added with it in the patch name.  It just means more work for a janitor later on.
Good point.  Our build system assumes that you're changing the package if you're building it, so enforces version control in the package name.  So yes, it has to stay.
"TIS" here means the "tis" in package name. All STX built packages have tis in the name, to differentiate with original centos packages.

I don't think we even need this patch.  If we're not patching the source, then we don't need tis (or STX) version numbers.  We're only stuck building it ourselves because a prebuilt version of it doesn't exist upstream, right?

templates/workarounds.sh.j2.message: Double and here - I don't think that will work.

I think you could apply a default here quite simply, to remove the if/then/else condition and also remove the default from the function above.

This seems to work right:

- hosts: localhost
  connection: local
  gather_facts: no
  vars:
    pre_undercloud_update_workarounds:
    - rhbz1:
        patch: true
        basedir: /usr/share/openstack-tripleo-heat-templates
        id: 112345
    - rhbz2:
        patch: true
        basedir: /usr/share/openstack-tripleo-heat-templates
        patch_strip: 2
        id: 212321
    - rhbz3:
        patch: true
        basedir: /usr/share/openstack-tripleo-heat-templates
        patch_strip: ""
        id: 23987
  tasks:
    - debug:
        msg: |
          {% for bugs in pre_undercloud_update_workarounds -%}
          {%     for key, value in bugs.items() -%}
          echo {{ key }}
          {%         if value.patch -%}
          {%             set _patch_strip = value.patch_strip | default(1, True) -%}
          apply_patch {{ value.basedir }} {{ value.id }} {{ _patch_strip }}
          {%         endif -%}
          {%     endfor %}
          {% endfor %}

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
I may be wrong but IMHO this is also dangerous. Let me explain:

- If an error occurs while deleting a port, let's say because the DNS entries associated to that port have already been deleted, then the rev number is not deleted.
- This will make the Maintenance task to attempt the deletion of the port in OVN in (at most) 5 minutes.
- This deletion will likely fail for the same reason
- This repeats forever

In this case, the bug that this patch is partially addressing will still be there as instances with "duplicated" IP addresses will be unable to delete metadata.

I think that a better approach would be to use if_exists=True in the txn commands and ignore the RowNotFound for the associated objects. For example, if we leave behind a DNS entry for whatever reason it'd be harmless (and fixable) but if we don't delete the port it'll have the consequences described in the bug.

Thoughts?

I don't agree with the last two bullet points here. If the DNS entry is already, the next time we attempt to delete the port the DNS entry will not be included in the transaction. The idea is prevent the maintenance task to lose track of the resources it has to fix (even if it takes 2 cycles, we are aiming to eventual consistency of dbs).

I like the if_exists=True idea as well but I think both changes complement each other.

Also, ports are the only resource where we were checking for RowNotFound.
Fair enough! Thanks a lot for clarifying, it makes sense.

The benefit is that it does what was originally intended. Up through queens, an unrecognized filter param name ('ids') was silently ignored, so all address_scopes were being returned. In rocky, the request fails. See the following from https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/network/v2/:

Starting from Rocky release, the Networking API will perform validation on filtering attributes if the API extension filter-validation is available. If an API request contains an unknown or unsupported parameter, the server will return a 400 response instead of silently ignoring the invalid input.

roles/configure-podman-registry/README.m.message:
Upstream?

Why doesn't the use-builds-registry role work for this use case?  It is tested in the zuul-jobs-test-registry-podman job.

Oops, s/upstream//

The goal is to make the use-buildset-registry role include that role for podman. The reason is that this is not related to buildset-registry or docker, and that role can be used for intermediate-registry too.

Another issue is that for the intermediate registry, at least when it is configured using kubernetes cert-manager, the `cert` value needs to be set with the `ca.crt` file, not the `tls.crt` file (otherwise `podman push` fails with `x509: certificate signed by unknown authority`)

Right, I mentioned DHCP here because in OVN the DHCP Request packet never leaves the hypervisor. The local ovn-controller replies to the DHCP requests of the VMs running on that hypervisor.

But, with SR-IOV, since the hypervisor is skipped we should setup those external ports to handle these requests.

Only E/W routing with routers that don't have a gateway attached will work.

Yes. There's HA but all the SRIOV ports will be served DHCP and metadata from the same active node.

I don't have the numbers but the number of flows in these nodes shouldn't be too high. No need to do it now but we could try to determine how many OpenFlow rules each external port contribute and better assess how big the problem is (if at all).

Yeah, I can mention it but I don't want to be going into too much detail about bridge-mappings here.

East/West traffic on VLAN tenant network won't work either *if the router has a gateway port attached to it*.

If the router doesn't have a gateway, then E/W will work. This is due to the lack of routing flows when a gw is present as such port will have the 'reside-on-redirect' option [0].

Likely, the routing limitations will go away when we support DVR on VLAN tenant nets.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
This isn't quite accurate. All official projects should be using this upper-constraints file which is what will set the upper limit for the projects.

But this looks good and is how we've handled other libraries that have dropped py2 support to allow py3 runtimes to use the newer versions while restricting the (very few) projects still running py2 to use the last version available for that runtime.

Swift is really the only one that should be still using py2, so if this isn't used by swift, we can just drop the cap and use the latest version in the upper constraints. But until we clean up the other py2 upper constraints, I think this is probably the best route to go.

If you change the docker's api_url (https://github.com/openstack/kolla-ansible/blob/master/ansible/roles/zun/templates/zun.conf.j2#L116) to 'unix:///var/run/docker.sock', you will find that the docker doesn't work either (unless you restart the docker daemon after).

From https://github.com/containerd/containerd/blob/master/docs/man/containerd-config.toml.5.md, the default ownership is root/root. As a container you'd need pid_mode=host (and sudo in the container) to get to real uid 0.

We can go with the approach you have here, since it only affects zun.
I actually spent weeks for finding a work around for this issue. However, I couldn't find a really "better" solution. If anyone can find a good alternative approach, please point it out.
But most environments will not have the above config, so will need to restart containerd to add it.
The trick is that the zun user doesn't exist until the zun containers are deployed. After that, we can add zun user a a group. Then, restart containerd. Therefore, all containers are disrupted.
I think Mark meant existing deployments, not new.
But you need to restart containerd to pick up this configuration.

Folks,

Please let me know how to proceed with this. If there is an alternative approach that can work, just let me know how to do it.

If we add zun user to a group like this: https://github.com/openstack/kolla/blob/master/docker/zun/zun-compute/extend_start.sh , it requires a restart of containerd to pick up the permission. A containerd restart will disrupt all the containers in docker, which is not desirable.

We can add it and restart containerd when all the other containers are not deployed yet, but we cannot add it and restart when all the other containers are deployed.

However, if we want to add the specific user "zun", we need to wait for the zun containers are deployed so this user is there. At this stage, all the other containers are deployed. If we restart containerd at this time, it will hit the problem.
Right. We restart containerd on server bootstrap stage in here, which is OK. We get into problem if we restart containerd when all the containers are deployed.

For one, we could limit this containerd dance to hosts deploying zun-cni-daemon container. And also add this restart fact to docs (but this is of bootstrap in general I think, it can be disruptive for other reasons).

Right now, kolla-ansible containers cannot tolerate a restart, because restarting containerd will change all the containers from "Running" to "Stopped". There might be other effects as well. We should avoid such restart unless it is necessary.

playbookconfig/src/playbooks/roles/commo.message: storage images are optional and should not be included here. The list is already extended on line 99.

we should always download the storage image for Distributed cloud scenarios. In that type of setup, subclouds can be configured to use the docker registry of the central cloud. If subclouds want to use snapshots, they will not be able to pull this image at bootstrap because it will not be present on the central cloud.

So even if it is an optional feature, it should be configured independently between central cloud and subclouds. 

Also, this additional image is only pulled here, the enabling of the service is controller by another bootstrap variable.

BOOT_DEVICE="$(get_disk $boot_device)p"

[It always worked in the past, so it should work now too see nvme detection in: sysinv/api/controllers/v1/partition.py +409:
    if partitions:
        if constants.DEVICE_NAME_NVME in idisk.device_node:
            device_node = "%sp%s" %\

        else:

]

bsp-files/kickstarts/pre_disk_setup_comm.message: There are numerous possibilities besides "sda". User could install to "sdc" for example, depending on lab config, not to mention NVME drive

This is not safe for two reasons:
1. It doesn't work with NVMe's - partitions there are identified as "${rootfs_disk}p1", "${rootfs_disk}p2" ...
2. There are many cases that will hit this condition - getting a disk from another deployment. A better mechanism should be used.

A good alternative used in the past is to set the partition GUID using something like:

BACKUP_PART_LABEL="System Backup"
BACKUP_PART_NO=1 #or 2 for EFI
BACKUP_PART_GUID=ba5eba11-0000-1111-2222-000000000002
# Note that in sysinv constants.py you will find ba5eba11-0000-1111-2222- as the prefix used by STX and
# ba5eba11-0000-1111-2222-000000000001 used by custom stx LVM partitions.
# Please add a comment in constants.py after that definition to say that we now also use 000000000002
and a note here, in pre_disk_setup_common.cfg, specifying how it is derived and that 000000000001 is used by LVM partitions.
sgdisk --change-name=$BACKUP_PART_NO:"$BACKUP_PART_LABEL" --typecode=$BACKUP_PART_NO:$BACKUP_PART_GUID

Then to check if the type is correct see the code in pre_disk_setup_common.cfg:

part_type_guid_str="Partition GUID code"
CEPH_OSD_GUID="4FBD7E29-9D25-41B8-AFD0-062C0CEFF05D"
[...]
            for part_number in "${part_numbers[@]}"; do
                sgdisk_part_info=$(flock $dev sgdisk -i $part_number $dev)
                part_type_guid=$(echo "$sgdisk_part_info" | grep "$part_type_guid_str" | awk '{print $4;}')
                if [ "$part_type_guid" == $CEPH_OSD_GUID ]; then
                    echo "OSD found on $dev, skipping wipe"
                    wipe_dev="false"
                    break
                fi
            done

before removing the partition you also need to wipe at the beginning and the end of it with something like:
    echo "Pre-wiping $p from kickstart"
    dd if=/dev/zero of=$p bs=512 count=34
    dd if=/dev/zero of=$p bs=512 count=34 seek=$((`blockdev --getsz $p` - 34))

This can be dangerous if BACKUP_CREATED is 1 as you may loose the backup partition altogether, I recommend running it only is BACKUP_CREATED is 0.

Also, better use parted -s $dec mktable gpt as we actually recreating the GPT partitin table.

The constant defined in sysinv/common/constants.py is PARTITION_USER_MANAGED_GUID_PREFIX = "ba5eba11-0000-1111-2222-"
Is this case-sensitive?

Yes because I've seen that all the GUID codes are lowercase in sysinv but the 'sgdisk' utility always report in uppercase. Sysinv also uses 'sgdisk' when reporting these GUID codes but they are converted in lowercase in sysinv/agent/partition.py in the 'get_partition_info' function.

cinder/volume/drivers/rbd.py.message: Should we add a note on how this  can be inefficient but how the alternative is a nightmare to handle in the driver?
maybe it's just me but i was expecting a comment regarding the problems in using the clone snapshot functionality to do the revert and why we aren't doing that here.

I think the comment is missing the most important point, because even if you mention that you know that there is a problem and what's the recommended alternative, you don't mention WHY we still do it.

On the other hand we could provide a hint that better performance is achieved if they use BlueStore in Ceph.


Basically a short version of what you say in the release notes.  ;-)

IMO, this is a backend issue.  Sure, we could try to fake it in the driver, but that introduces a bunch of logic in the driver that really doesn't need to be there, and which will introduce bugs.  A lot of backends are able to do this functionality efficiently, and if the efficiency of this operation becomes an issue, it should be addressed in the backend.

It seems like an easy thing to do, right?  We just do a clone here and rename the resulting volume and the end user thinks a revert has happened.  However, as far as the backend is concerned, it's a different image, and all the snapshots etc. associated in the backend with the original volume are not associated with this new thing.  So we'd have to stuff to change all these associations.  And it gets worse.  If you want a sense of how big a nightmare it can become, talk to Jon Bernard.

The point of my comment here is just to flag that the backend acknowledges that this is an inefficient operation, there's not an easy way to speed it up out here in the driver.

https://github.com/golang/lint/blob/master/testdata/contextkeytypes.go#L16

from what i understand it should be a type instead of basic string.
Ok this seems official recommendation from context module
nit: this can be 120 lines, so wrapping is not necessary.

Here is the official recommended documentation: https://golang.org/pkg/context/#WithValue

Why are we exporting this? I don't think we want to allow usage of the same retries in other packages without an explicit reason for doing so.

While it's true that we are avoiding using the basic string type, the reason is so that this package does not conflict with other packages that also add "numRetries" as a key.

My recommendation would be to document that so it's clear. Something like:

  // contextKey is used by the redfish package as a unique key type in order to prevent collisions with context keys in other packages.
  type contextKey string

Shouldn't we prefer to make this global so it can be used by the entire package?

I would recommend:

  var ctxKeyNumRetries contextKey = "numRetries"

pkg/document/plugin/templater/v1alpha1/t.message: nit: need a newline between license and package name (golint pkg/document/plugin/templater/v1alpha1/templater.go)
this is a great example of the sort of use case this can be applied to.

We'll likely want to template in values that are defined and used elsewhere.  Have you though about / tested using the ReplacementTransformer as a first plugin, to get this config set up first, and then the Templater as a second plugin?

If that works cleanly it would probably be a good Plan A.  An alternative might be for the Templater to "find" its configuration among the input documents using GVK, in which case those documents can be easily populated from other sources like catalogues of networking info.

What I was meant was:  can we use the RT (or something else) to inject IPs into the generator config, or do we have to hard-code the IPs in the generator config?

The "define in the generator config" approach is fine if nothing else needs the IPs.  However, if other docs need those IPs, we'd ideally centralize them in one place.

We can do both approaches. I'm completely with you, that we must centralize everything in one place. I think generators may use 'catalogs' or even transformer configs, (since they are all yamls) as a source of truth when they generate their data. Since we 'own' this plugin, we can make it like we want to achieve that goal. Another approach is to allow them to generate 'initial' version of yamls, but have transformer to correct the needed info according to the catalogs during transformation step. It's anyway better than to keep lots of same files.

@Matt, first of all - this is a generator, not a transformer. They don't overlap. Transformers can't add resources, they just modify them. Generators are needed to add resources. Let's say, you need to add 40 nodes, each node - 1 yaml. generator will create 40 yamls from a single config. transformer can update these 40 yamls, but to create them you either need 40 files that look very much the same or generator. if you choose to have 40 files, that will be very cumbersome to make little changes, like let's say 'add 1 field' in future.
could we put a blank line here for readability?

I think "spec" might be a confusing name here, since it's normally used to denote the desired state of a kubernetes resource.

Perhaps "values" would be better? It'd be congruent to Helm's values.yaml, so it should be fairly familiar
